skill.name: error-tracking
skill.description: Add Sentry v8 error tracking and performance monitoring to your project services. Use this skill when adding error handling, creating new controllers, instrumenting cron jobs, or tracking database performance. ALL ERRORS MUST BE CAPTURED TO SENTRY - no exceptions.

security_audit.summary: This skill is a pure documentation file containing only markdown and code examples for Sentry v8 integration. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or filesystem access. The skill provides safe, standard patterns for error tracking.

content.value_statement: Production errors are hard to debug without centralized monitoring. This skill provides ready-to-use patterns for Sentry v8 integration including error handling, performance monitoring, and database tracing.
actual_capabilities: Add Sentry error handling to controllers using BaseController pattern
Instrument cron jobs with Sentry performance spans
Track database query performance with DatabasePerformanceMonitor
Capture workflow errors with context using WorkflowSentryHelper
Configure Sentry initialization with proper DSN and environment settings
limitations: Does not install or configure Sentry SDK automatically
Does not provide running Sentry instance or server
Requires existing Sentry account and DSN credentials
Patterns target Node.js TypeScript services only

output_examples.input: Add Sentry error handling to my new user controller
output: Controller extends BaseController with built-in Sentry error handling
All try/catch blocks automatically capture exceptions to Sentry
User context and service tags included in error reports
Appropriate error levels (fatal, error, warning) applied

best_practices: Always use BaseController or Sentry.captureException instead of console.error alone
Include meaningful context (user ID, service name, operation type) with every error
Import instrument.ts as the first line in cron jobs to enable tracing
anti_patterns: Using console.error without Sentry capture - errors are lost
Swallowing errors silently without logging or reporting
Exposing sensitive data (passwords, tokens) in error context or messages

faq.question: Which Sentry SDK versions are supported?
faq.answer: This skill supports Sentry v8 for Node.js with TypeScript. Patterns may need adjustment for older versions.

faq.question: What is the performance impact of Sentry tracing?
faq.answer: Recommended sample rates are 0.1 (10%) for traces and profiles to minimize overhead while gathering useful data.

faq.question: How do I connect this to my existing Sentry project?
faq.answer: Set the SENTRY_DSN environment variable in your config. The DSN is the connection string from your Sentry project settings.

faq.question: Is my code data sent to Sentry servers?
faq.answer: Error details and performance data are sent to your configured Sentry DSN endpoint. Sensitive data should not be included in error context.

faq.question: Why are my errors not appearing in Sentry?
faq.answer: Check that SENTRY_DSN is set, instrument.ts is imported before other code, and errors use captureException or handleError method.

faq.question: How does this compare to other monitoring tools?
faq.answer: Sentry provides focused error tracking with performance monitoring. It integrates well with Node.js services and provides detailed stack traces and context.
